I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  country  programming  mission  held  on  4–6  August  2015  in  Beijing,  the 
Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  confirmed  its  request  to  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) for a new facility-type technical assistance (TA) project that will 
provide flexible and timely response to emerging policy and capacity development needs during 
2016–2020. An important tool that enhances ADB's ability to respond quickly and flexibly, the 
facility-type TA is also an important means to support and disseminate innovation, and serve 
different objectives of ADB’s country partnership strategy (CPS) and PRC reform priorities.1 The 
proposed TA is the eighth facility-type TA project in the PRC.2 The first six of these projects 
have been completed, while the Support for Deepening Policy Reform and Capacity Building 
project is still ongoing but with its funds already fully committed. 
 
2.  Continuing  policy  recommendations  and  capacity  building  are  critical  for  the  PRC 
government to quickly and effectively formulate and execute policies to address the economic 
and social development challenges under the “new normal.”3 In addition, the implementation 
period of the proposed TA will coincide with the initial implementation period of the Thirteenth 
Five-Year Plan on National Economic and Social Development, 2016–2020.4 This TA also 
supports the implementation of the country knowledge plan for the PRC in terms of knowledge 
generation and sharing.5 The TA fact-finding mission took place in May 2016, and an agreement 
was  reached  with  the  executing  agency—the  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)—on  the  impact, 
outcome, outputs, costs, implementation arrangements, and terms of reference (TOR). The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.6 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  While the PRC has made significant progress in overall economic growth since 1978, 
the country still has considerable work to do to reach a moderately prosperous and harmonious 
society by 2020. Excessive reliance on investment, exports, and industrial development in the 
past has created imbalances and structural constraints, such as low factor productivity resulting 
from  overinvestment  and  excess  capacity,  growing  income  and  regional  disparities,  and

Policy Reform and Capacity Building. Manila (TA 8780, $800,000, approved on 3 December). 
3  The “new normal” means that the Chinese economy has entered a new phase that is different from the high-speed 
growth pattern exhibited in the past. It is a new trend that features more sustainable, mid- to high-speed growth 
with higher efficiency and lower costs.

2
environmental concerns. This led the government to question the soundness of the growth 
model. Under the “new normal,” which focuses on quality rather than quantity of economic 
growth, the PRC’s economy faces numerous challenges: declining factor productivity, widening 
income inequality and urban–rural gap, increasing environmental degradation and pollution, and 
growing resource constraints. Other constraints arise from economic rebalancing, the downside 
of  urbanization,  weak  institutional  capacity,  poor  policy  coordination  between  government 
agencies, and, above all, the need to restructure PRC institutions from being led by economic 
growth to becoming public-service-oriented entities that can respond to emerging problems. 
 
4.  The 13th plan, approved by the National People’s Congress in March 2016, outlines a 
policy  framework,  government  priorities,  and  economic  and  social  development  targets, 
including  medium–high  economic  growth,  inclusive  and  innovation-driven  development, 
ecological civilization and green development, and the establishment of a modern social sector. 
 
5.  The  completed  facility-type  TA  projects  contributed  to  the  implementation  of  the 
government’s priority areas in previous five-year plans; enabled policy analyses on emerging, 
urgent issues; and strengthened the capacity of the executing and implementing agencies.7 
Building on the success of and lessons learned from previous facility-type TA projects, the 
proposed TA will provide the PRC government with policy inputs, tools, and a forum to best 
respond to the development challenges and achieve the targets of the 13th plan. 
 
III.  THE POLICY AND ADVISORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The  impact  will  be  the  formulation  of  an  effective  policy  for  implementing  key 
socioeconomic development goals of the 13th plan, and capacity enhancement of relevant 
government  agencies  based  on  timely  and  quality  policy  research  and  capacity-building 
programs.  The  outcome  of  the  TA  will  be  policy  reforms,  strategies,  and  new  ideas  and 
practices introduced or recommended for adoption by relevant government agencies, along with 
capacity building in priority areas. Indicators and performance targets are those that have been 
set out in the CPS and the 13th plan, particularly those related to inclusive and innovation-
driven development, ecological civilization and green development, and other key economic and 
development goals. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  The TA will allow ADB to provide timely support for PRC reform processes and capacity 
building, and its design provides a flexible framework, including allowing the selection of some 
subprojects during TA implementation. Subprojects will be jointly selected to provide timely 
                                                
7  Independent Evaluation Department. 2013. Performance Evaluation Report: People’s Republic of China: Facility-
Type Technical Assistance. Manila: ADB. The report recommended that ADB continue to work with “facility-type” 
TA and replicate such engagement in other member countries to increase goodwill for the wider ADB country 
portfolio.  The report also pointed out the main lessons from previous facility type TAs that need to be addressed in 
future TAs: the effectiveness of facility type TAs could be improved if consultant procurement time frames were 
shortened and if ADB could assign adequate staff to work simultaneously on multiple subprojects at various stages 
of the subproject cycle (design, processing, implementation, and monitoring of outputs and outcomes).  To improve 
the effectiveness of the new facility type TA, the resident mission will (i) work closely with the Operations Services 
and Financial Management Department to shorten the consultant recruitment time frames; and (ii) administer the 
new facility type TA, with counterparts from ADB headquarters contributing to and/or managing some subprojects 
simultaneously at various stages of subproject design, processing, implementation and monitoring, based on their 
technical strengths and complementarity to other ADB programs.

3 
support to emerging government reform and capacity-building priorities in areas where ADB 
involvement  is  expected  to  have  substantial  impact  on  development,  refinement,  and/or 
operationalization of national policy; and which are consistent with the CPS and complementary 
to ADB lending and TA operations. Policy-related activities may include formulation and/or 
amendment of policies, laws, and regulations; and the design or refinement of institutional 
structures, operational procedures, and capacity-building mechanisms. 
 
8.  Output  1:  Policy  assessments  enhanced.  The  subprojects  under  this  output  will 
provide  policy  advice  to  selected  central  and  provincial  government  agencies  on  priority 
development issues in different sectors and subjects to respond to emerging challenges and 
support  the  implementation  of  the  13th  plan,  and  in  other  priority  sectors  agreed  by  the 
government and ADB. Activities will include research studies, policy dialogue, and stakeholder 
consultation through meetings, workshops, and conferences. The indicative allotment for this 
output is $600,000. 
 
9.  Output  2:  Capacity  building  in  selected  agencies/areas  strengthened.  The 
subprojects  under  this  output  will  allow  to  strengthen  the  development  and  management 
capacity of selected central and provincial government agencies through capacity assessments, 
training programs, workshops, conferences, and knowledge management interventions. The 
indicative allotment for this output is $200,000. 
 
10.  The PRC  Resident  Mission  and  MOF  will jointly  screen  and  select  subprojects  for 
funding under these two outputs according to a set of pre-identified selection criteria. The 
criteria for selecting policy-related subprojects require that a subproject (i) supports priority 
government policy reforms and local innovations, consistent with the CPS; (ii) aligns with the 
implementation of the 13th plan; (iii) considers emerging, urgent, and high-priority issues where 
ADB can potentially add considerable value; and (iv) shows evidence of strong PRC ownership, 
such that a small amount of strategic ADB assistance will help push forward or better actualize 
important reforms and/or leverage the outcome and impact of existing projects. Priority will be 
given to capacity-building subprojects that support cooperation between the PRC and ADB in 
addressing the key development constraints highlighted in para. 3. 
 
11.  The indicative subprojects identified for output 1 include: (i) Social Work Services Policy 
and Delivery Modes for Migrant Children in the PRC, which aims to develop standards for social 
work services for migrant children in the PRC ($100,000); (ii) Study on the Construction of 
Scientific and Technological Innovation Center Promoted by the Enhancement of Science and 
Technology  Parks,  which  aims  to  facilitate  the  construction  of  a  science  and  technology 
innovation center in Shanghai ($100,000); (iii) Integrated Resource Conservation Project—A 
Case Study in Tianjin, which aims to build a recycling economy and a demonstration base for 
ecological civilization in Tianjin ($100,000); and (iv) Study of the Key Issues in Legislating the 
PRC’s Futures Market, which aims to promote the development and legislation of the futures 
market in the PRC ($100,000). 
 
12.  Throughout the 3-year implementation period, additional subprojects are expected to be 
included under the proposed TA. The selection criteria of new subprojects will follow those 
specified in para. 10. Periodic meetings between ADB and MOF will be held to update the list of 
subprojects and core outputs. A memorandum of understanding between ADB and MOF will be 
signed to record the agreement on additional subprojects. The resident mission country director 
will seek MOF’s concurrence on the updated TA subproject list, attaching the memorandum of 
understanding as recorded, including (i) an updated list of subprojects with detailed project 
designs and specific TORs, and (ii) reports on the implementation progress of all TA subprojects.

4
The first meeting between ADB and MOF will be held immediately after TA approval to finalize 
arrangements and timetables for first-round activities. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost the equivalent of $1,000,000, of which ADB will provide an 
equivalent  of  $800,000  on  a  grant  basis  under ADB’s  Technical Assistance  Special  Fund 
(TASF-other sources). The government will provide counterpart support in the form of office 
venue and supplies, counterpart staff, and other in-kind contributions. The cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2, and estimated budgets for indicative initial subprojects are 
noted above. Subsequent subprojects will be subject to a maximum of $100,000 each, unless 
this ceiling is waived by ADB and MOF. 
 
14.  Subprojects  may  also  fund  surveys,  field  investigations,  the  purchase  of  required 
research materials, and other related expenditures under output 1 on the basis of cost estimates 
agreed by ADB in advance. In line with standard ADB procedures, the TA will not support 
implementing agencies’ management fees, overhead expenses, or related costs such as staff 
salaries and allowances; and the use of implementing agencies’ resources (such as office 
accommodation), which will be provided as part of the counterpart contribution. The support for 
workshops under output 2 may include costs related to venue and equipment rental; translation 
and/or  interpretation;  material  editing,  copying,  printing,  and/or  dissemination;  food  and 
nonalcoholic beverages; transportation; lodging; logistics and administrative support; and other 
expenditures with prior approval from ADB. Recruitment of consultants will be undertaken in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to 
time).  The  proceeds  of  the TA  will  be  disbursed  in  line  with  ADB's  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The TA will be implemented from 20 July 2016 through 19 June 2019. MOF will be the 
executing agency for the TA and will be responsible for oversight and coordination of subproject 
activities. ADB will closely monitor the implementation progress and record the status of each 
subproject monthly or as needed. To ensure strong coordination, ADB and MOF will meet 
quarterly or as needed to review progress and discuss candidates for additional subprojects, 
assess  core  outputs,  and  ensure  effective  dissemination.  In  coordination  with  MOF  and 
implementing  agencies,  ADB  will  produce  the  implementation  progress  report  for  each 
subproject quarterly. 
 
16.  Throughout the 3-year implementation period, ADB and MOF will continuously accept 
subproject  proposals  from  government  organizations,  various  institutions,  nongovernment 
organizations, and, in special cases, a unit within ADB or MOF. Based on the proposed TA 
design and selection criteria, ADB and MOF will jointly agree on subprojects to be included in 
the  TA,  and  on  the  responsible  implementing  agencies.  For  each  agreed  subproject,  the 
implementing agency will take overall responsibility for ensuring coordination and the quality 
and timeliness of output delivery. It will identify one focal point to provide working-level inputs 
throughout the subproject, including (i) liaising with ADB, MOF, and additional key actors and 
decision makers to support implementation and policy dialogue; (ii) identifying, proposing to 
ADB and MOF, and coordinating with external subproject experts all activities, specific written 
inputs, and review of key draft reports; and (iii) proposing to ADB and MOF any changes 
needed in subproject scope or approaches based on discussion with the experts.

5 
17.  ADB staff will monitor, and in some cases directly contribute to, TA progress and outputs, 
and will conduct policy discussions with relevant government agencies. The resident mission 
will  administer  the  TA,  with  counterparts  from  ADB  headquarters  contributing  to  and/or 
managing some subprojects, based on their technical strengths and complementarity to other 
ADB programs. 
 
18.  ADB  will  work  with  the  government  to  identify  national  (58  person-months)  and 
international (12 person-months) specialists to provide inputs as individual consultants, resource 
persons, and task-specific experts. ADB will endorse the required expertise and the TOR, 
including the duration and expected results, at the time of joint identification of subprojects or 
during implementation. In dialogue with MOF and/or relevant implementing agencies, ADB will 
recruit consultants in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as 
amended from time to time) and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB. Additional resource 
persons and task-specific experts will carry out well-defined tasks (e.g., case study papers, 
workshop presentations, and review of draft reports). TA projects involving more than three 
consultants  should  typically  use  firm-based  recruitment;  but  given  the  need  for  flexibility, 
responsiveness, and timeliness, as well as the fact that a sizable portion of TA activities and 
expert inputs cannot be identified at the time of processing, this requirement will be waived. 
 
19.   ADB will disburse funds linked to other activity expenditures based on costed work 
plans submitted by the implementing agency and jointly reviewed by MOF. Unless otherwise 
agreed,  funds  will  be  disbursed  directly  to  the  implementing  agencies.  In  all  cases,  the 
implementing agencies will provide documentation to liquidate actual expenditures to ADB in 
accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). To facilitate implementation, ADB may establish an advance payment facility for 
MOF  and  the  implementing  agencies  as  needed  and/or  utilize  direct  payments  (e.g.,  to 
workshop venues). The resident mission will provide an orientation to ensure clarity on related 
procedures. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to 
the People’s Republic of China for the Facility for Strengthening Policy Reform and Capacity 
Building project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The proposed technical assistance (TA) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to the 
People's Republic of China (PRC) will recruit 58 person-months of national consultant expertise 
and 12 person-months of international expert inputs to support research, workshops, and other 
agreed subproject activities. The inputs will be provided by consultants, resource persons, and 
other task-specific experts, and will serve to introduce international good practices; provide in-
depth visions and knowledge; and/or advise on policy options, challenges, knowledge solutions, 
and the implications of various courses of action. The nature of the needed expertise and inputs 
will  be  determined  on  a  case-by-case  basis  for  each  activity  or  subproject  identified  and 
approved jointly by the implementing agencies, the executing agency (through the knowledge 
cooperation and TA division of the Ministry of Finance), and ADB (through the country director 
of the PRC Resident Mission). 
 
2.  ADB will recruit consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2013, as amended from time to time). The implementing agencies will be responsible for 
proposing the terms of reference (TOR) to the Ministry of Finance and ADB for consideration. 
The  experts  may  be  independent  consultants  or  recruited  from  consulting  firms,  research 
institutes, think tanks, academic institutions, government research arms, and nongovernment 
organizations  (NGOs).  The  qualification  requirements  for  each  expert  will  be  defined  in 
consultation with the implementing agencies before initiating the selection. 
 
A.  Consultants (9 person-months, international; 40 person-months, national) 
 
3.  Indicative tasks of consultants for subprojects under output 1 of the TA are: 
(i)  Assist  the  executing  agency  and/or  implementing  agencies  and  ADB  in 
identifying and/or refining the topical coverage, content, and/or methodology of 
the study and related activities, which should focus on strategic development 
issues of the PRC and be consistent with the government’s prioritized strategies 
and ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2016–2020 for the PRC.1 
(ii)  Undertake specific research and analysis, as required in the TOR prepared by 
relevant implementing agencies and endorsed by the executing agency and ADB. 
International experts, in particular, should provide advice and other inputs on 
reform frameworks and processes based on international comparative analyses 
and best practices for incorporation into final policy recommendations. 
(iii)  Work with the implementing agencies to produce study reports and/or policy 
synopsis in the format required by ADB for satisfying the TA requirements (e.g., 
policy research studies, assessment reports, policy notes, good-practice analysis, 
and related sector and/or thematic reports). 
(iv)  Be responsible for quality control of the final bilingual TA synopsis (in English and 
Chinese). 
(v)  Contribute to policy dialogue with and knowledge solutions for key government 
decision makers and other stakeholders, and the dissemination of the TA output. 
 
4.  Indicative tasks of consultants for subprojects under output 2 of the TA are: 
(i)  Conduct a detailed human resource and/or institutional needs assessment for 
relevant government agencies and/or nongovernment entities, which includes

identifying gaps and key obstacles and/or constraints that limit the institutional 
capacities. 
(ii)  Propose to ADB and the implementing agencies capacity-building action plans 
that include experience-based methodologies applying case studies and multiple 
tools, such as face-to-face training and print-based resources. 
(iii)  Design and conduct training-of-trainers to support capacity building for central 
and local government officials, executing agency and/or implementing agencies, 
NGOs, and other beneficiaries, as required. 
(iv)  Organize  and  contribute  inputs  to  conferences,  seminars,  workshops,  focus 
group  meetings,  training  sessions,  and  other  events  to  promote  PRC–ADB 
strategic partnership development, and knowledge sharing and dissemination. 
 
B.  Task-Specific Experts (6 person-months, national) 
 
5.  The task-specific experts provide technical and/or administrative inputs in their areas of 
expertise to support TA implementation and quality control, when needed. The task-specific 
experts will support the executing agency and/or implementing agencies in liaising with ADB 
and other key stakeholders to ensure effective policy dialogues and smooth TA implementation, 
coordinating with subproject experts, reviewing and polishing TA report and/or policy synopsis, 
and reporting to the executing agency and/or implementing agencies and ADB. Among the 
specific tasks are: 
(i)  Liaise with relevant focal points for other national and internationally supported 
initiatives, ensuring communication and dovetailing of efforts across agencies 
and/or organizations and administrative levels. 
(ii)  Update the executing agency and/or implementing agencies and ADB on TA 
progress and help manage issues arising from TA implementation. 
(iii)  Provide technical and/or administrative inputs based on specific TORs agreed by 
the executing agency and/or implementing agencies and ADB. 
 
C.  Resource Persons (3 person-months, international; 12 person-months, national; not 
exceeding 10 working days each) 
 
6.  Unless otherwise agreed by the executing agency and/or implementing agencies and 
ADB, resource persons or experts entitled to receive honoraria or payments to be identified by 
the responsible executing agency and/or implementing agencies and ADB include the following: 
(i)  presenters, facilitators, and panelists for various workshops and events (including 
conferences, training seminars, and knowledge-sharing activities); 
(ii)  representatives of various agencies (e.g., academia, NGOs, private sector) and 
other individuals recommended by the executing agency and/or implementing 
agencies and selected by ADB to (a) act as discussants on related policy issues; 
(b) present fact findings, research results, and policy advice and/or suggestions; 
and (c) review reports and/or comment on selected research; and 
(iii)  researchers that implementing agencies have commissioned to prepare studies 
on specific topics agreed by the executing agency and/or implementing agencies 
and ADB.
